Award.AwardTitle: Mineral Surface-Mediated Processes in Protocell Evolution: Membrane Self-Assembly and Emergence of Energy Transduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
(1) Technical abstract

We propose that geochemical aqueous environment chemistry played an important role in selecting lipid membrane compositions that were stable (survival of the fittest protocells). We will use model "protocells" consisting of single-chain, multi-component amphiphile vesicles as a prebiotic analog to biological membrane-forming lipids. We will determine which mixed amphiphile compositions are stable under changing environmental solution conditions. Surviving vesicle populations will be quantitatively identified by fluorometry and UV-Vis spectroscopy and fittest amphiphile concentrations will be determined by high-pressure liquid chromatography. These vesicle compositions will be considered as the "fittest." Vesicle stability will be examined for a wide range of solution pHs and in the absence or presence of dissolved salts (NaCl, KCl, NaBr, CaCl2, MgCl2, MgSO4, each at 0.01 and 0.1M concentrations). For a smaller number of samples, we will also examine the temperature-dependence of vesicle stability. These conditions will represent a wide range of geochemical environments, such as freshwater, alkaline or acidic lake water, intertidal zone water and seawater. Results will have implications for determining which geochemical environments would have provided a selection pressure for survival of the fittest protocells.

(2) Broader significance

This project aims to understand a critical aspect of the evolution of life, namely in figuring out how cells, the building blocks of life, came to exist. An essential and critical component of cells is their membranes, which encase all of their contents. These membranes are made of lipids. In the history of the Earth, it is unknown what led to the formation of stable lipid membranes. This research seeks to address this mystery by examining the behavior of analogs to biological membrane-forming lipids under conditions that represent different natural environments. In particular, this study will examine the role that mineral surfaces can play in the formation of "protocells" from lipids.

In addition to this project's implications for the origin of life, increasing our fundamental understanding of the interaction between minerals and lipid membranes has implications for medical geology, nanomedicine, and the health/safety of nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals

The main aims were to test the hypothesis that environmental chemistry played a major role in determining the integrity of the membranes of the earliest protocells and, thus, their survival. Model membranes of different compositions were tested under different pHs (pH 2-12) and dissolved cation concentrations (Mg2+, Ca2+) conditions and in the presence of different minerals at circumneutral pHs to determine the most robust protocells ("survival of the fittest"). We examined two major aspects of protocell membrane stability: (i) the effects of mineral surfaces on membrane self-assembly rates, and (ii) the effects of divalent cations on membrane stability (permeability) and compositional evolution.

(i) Mineral effects: The self-assembly of bilayer membranes promoted by inorganic solids has been known for a decade yet, no unifying relationships between the properties of the minerals and amphiphile self-assembly were previously identified. We identified a structure-activity relation by systematically examining the influence of a wide range of minerals on single chain amphiphile (SCA) vesicle-formation rates, thermodynamic stability, membrane permeability and integrity.

(ii) Divalent cation effects: Protocell membranes were likely composed of SCAs, but pure SCA membranes are unstable towards divalent cations, which are ubiquitous in aqueous environments. Phospholipids (PLs) are more stable modern membrane-forming molecules. Prebiotic PL synthesis may have been possible in trace amounts. We examined how membranes evolved in composition from primitive SCAs towards PLs and showed for the first time that divalent cations promote this compositional evolution rather than acting only as “deleterious” agents.

 

Significant Results

(1)  Mineral effects: Vesicle formation rates were found to correlate with the isoelectric point (IEP), solubility and reactive surface area of (oxyhydr)oxides, carbonates, sulfides and aluminosilicate minerals. The IEP (which reflects surface charge) and solubility are quantitatively related to the chemical composition, crystal structure and surface hydration of the mineral. We also provided a model to explain how minerals promote membrane formation apparently even up to 10 nm away from the surface. Thus, protocell membrane formation at the emergence of life could have depended critically on the mineralogy of early Earth. The structure-activity relationships identified may help predict membrane stability on other solid worlds such as Mars, moons of Earth, Jupiter, Saturn and exo-solar planets, as well as in diverse other applications involving amphiphile-mineral interactions.

(2)  We showed that instead of being deleterious, Mg2+ and Ca2+ acted to evolve the mixed membrane composition towards PL enrichment by imposing an environmental selection pressure. Mg2+ preferentially binds to and abstracts OA from mixed OA-POPC lipid membranes, resulting in relatively PL-enriched vesicles. The effect was the most dramatic for the largest initial OA-POPC ratio representing the most primitive protocells. This is the first report of selective lipid abstraction from mixed SCA-PL vesicles. These results may hold implications for accommodating prebiotic Mg2+-promoted processes, such as non-enzymatic RNA polymerization.

 

Key Outcomes

(1)  Protocell membrane formation at the emergence of life could have depended critically on the mineralogy of the early Earth. The structure-activity relationships identified here may help predict the plausible stability of membranes on other solid worlds such as Mars, moons of Earth, Jupiter, Saturn and exo-solar planets, as well as in diverse other applications involving amphiphile-mineral interactions.

(2)  We have shown that instead of being deleterious, Mg2+ and Ca2+ acted to evolve the mixed membrane composition towards PL enrichment by imposing an environmental selection pressure.

(3) This work has resulted in two papers published in Scientific Reports (2017) and Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta (2018). One undergraduate research thesis in Biochemistry was completed.

(4) We also presented our research in invited talks and volunteered talks and posters at several conferences. Nita Sahai also gave numerous invited seminars at various Universities. Dr. Sahai was also invited to speak on Public Broadcasting Service, on National Public Radio and has also given many lectures at other public forums, including Cleveland Science Café, Cleveland Museum of Natural History and the Akron Center for Enquiry.

 

Impact

We have shown for the first time that protocell membrane formation at the emergence of life could have depended critically on the mineralogy of the early Earth. The structure-activity relationships identified here may help predict the plausible stability of membranes on other solid worlds such as Mars, moons of Earth, Jupiter, Saturn and exo-solar planets, as well as in diverse other applications involving amphiphile-mineral interactions.

Furthermore, We have shown that instead of being deleterious, Mg2+ and Ca2+ acted to evolve the mixed membrane composition towards PL enrichment by imposing an environmental selection pressure.

 

We have contributed to a broader understanding of amphiphile membrane stability and the effects of various environmental factors on these membranes. Such interactions are use relevant in applications as far ranging as drug delivery to ore biobeneficiation.
